commit_message:
New cinder driver to support Daowoo YeeSan

Add a cinder volume driver for Daowoo YeeSan storage. It includes the
minimum set of features. This driver introduces a new storage protocol
`yfs`, which is used in qemu and libvirt.

Implements: blueprint cinder-driver-for-yeesan
Change-Id: I6a3d2290ac326f24257af663c014596c4cf842a9
Depends-On: I3cc12f745c8db08673d45f4642d4f097b1f7ad82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/40/202440/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015, Daowoo Co.,Ltd. All Rights Reserved # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from oslo_concurrency import processutils as putils from cinder import exception from cinder.image import image_utils from cinder import test from cinder.volume.drivers.daowoo.yeesan import YeeSanDriver class YeeSanDriverTestCase(test.TestCase): """Test case for YFS driver.""" def setUp(self): super(YeeSanDriverTestCase, self).setUp() self._cfg = mock.MagicMock() self._cfg.yfs_pool = '1001' self._cfg.reserved_percentage = '0' self._cfg.yfs_mount_path = '/mnt/yfs' self._cfg.volume_backend_name = 'YeeSan' def safe_get(key): return getattr(self._cfg, key) self._cfg.safe_get = safe_get self._stats = {} self._driver = YeeSanDriver(configuration=self._cfg) self.volume_name_1 = u'volume-01' self.volume_name_2 = u'volume-02' self.snapshot_name = u'snapshot-01' self.volume_size = '1' self.volume_1 = dict(name=self.volume_name_1, size=self.volume_size) self.volume_2 = dict(name=self.volume_name_2, size=self.volume_size) self.snapshot = dict(volume_name=self.volume_name_1, name=self.snapshot_name) self.path = '/mnt/yfs/1001/volume.vol' def test_initialize_connection(self): drv = self._driver expected = { 'driver_volume_type': 'yfs', 'data': { 'name': 'volume-01', 'pool': '1001', 'protocol': 'yfs'} } conn_info = drv.initialize_connection(self.volume_1, None) self.assertDictMatch(expected, conn_info) def test_create_volume(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: drv.create_volume(self.volume_1) mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('qemu-img', 'create', 'yfs:/1001/volume-01', '1G', run_as_root=True) def test_create_cloned_volume(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_create_snapshot') as \ mock_create_snapshot, \ mock.patch.object(drv, '_create_volume_from_snapshot') as \ mock_create_volume_from_snapshot, \ mock.patch.object(drv, '_delete_snapshot') as \ mock_delete_snapshot: drv.create_cloned_volume(self.volume_2, self.volume_1) mock_create_snapshot.assert_called_once_with( 'volume-01', 'tempsnap_volume-01') mock_create_volume_from_snapshot.assert_called_once_with( 'volume-01', 'tempsnap_volume-01', 'volume-02') mock_delete_snapshot.assert_called_once_with( 'tempsnap_volume-01', 'volume-01') def test_copy_image_to_volume(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_local_path') as \ mock_local_path, \ mock.patch.object(drv, '_check_valid_device') as \ mock_check_valid_device, \ mock.patch.object(drv, '_extend_volume') as \ mock_extend_volume, \ mock.patch.object(image_utils, 'fetch_to_raw'): mock_local_path.return_value = '/mnt/yfs/1001' mock_check_valid_device.return_value = True mock_image_service = mock.MagicMock() drv.copy_image_to_volume(None, self.volume_1, mock_image_service, 'image-00112244') mock_extend_volume.assert_called_once_with('volume-01', '1') def test_copy_image_to_volume_raise(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_local_path') as \ mock_local_path, \ mock.patch.object(drv, '_check_valid_device') as \ mock_check_valid_device, \ mock.patch.object(drv, '_extend_volume'), \ mock.patch.object(image_utils, 'fetch_to_raw'): mock_local_path.return_value = '/mnt/yfs/1001' mock_check_valid_device.return_value = False mock_image_service = mock.MagicMock() self.assertRaises(exception.DeviceUnavailable, drv.copy_image_to_volume, None, self.volume_1, mock_image_service, 'image-00112244') def test_copy_volume_to_image(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_local_path') as \ mock_local_path, \ mock.patch.object(drv, '_check_valid_device') as \ mock_check_valid_device, \ mock.patch.object(image_utils, 'upload_volume'): mock_local_path.return_value = '/mnt/yfs/1001' mock_check_valid_device.return_value = True mock_image_service = mock.MagicMock() drv.copy_volume_to_image(None, self.volume_1, mock_image_service, {'id': '1234567890'}) def test_copy_volume_to_image_raise(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_local_path') as \ mock_local_path, \ mock.patch.object(drv, '_check_valid_device') as \ mock_check_valid_device, \ mock.patch.object(image_utils, 'upload_volume'): mock_local_path.return_value = '/mnt/yfs/1001' mock_check_valid_device.return_value = False mock_image_service = mock.MagicMock() self.assertRaises(exception.DeviceUnavailable, drv.copy_volume_to_image, None, self.volume_1, mock_image_service, {'id': '1234567890'}) def test_local_path(self): drv = self._driver self.assertEqual('/mnt/yfs/1001/volume-01', drv._local_path(self.volume_1)) def test_create_snapshot(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_create_snapshot') as \ mock_create_snapshot: drv.create_snapshot(self.snapshot) mock_create_snapshot.assert_called_once_with('volume-01', 'snapshot-01') def test_create_snapshot_execute(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: drv._create_snapshot(self.volume_name_1, self.snapshot_name) mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('qemu-img', 'snapshot', '-c', 'snapshot-01', 'yfs:/1001/volume-01', run_as_root=True) def test_delete_volume(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: drv.delete_volume(self.volume_2) mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('qemu-img', 'amend', '-o', 'cmd=del,img=/1001/volume-02', 'yfs:/root/root', '-f', 'yfs', run_as_root=True) def test_delete_snapshot(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_delete_snapshot') as \ mock_delete_snapshot: drv.delete_snapshot(self.snapshot) mock_delete_snapshot.assert_called_once_with('snapshot-01', 'volume-01') def test_delete_snapshot_execute(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: drv._delete_snapshot(self.snapshot_name, self.volume_name_1) mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('qemu-img', 'snapshot', '-d', 'snapshot-01', 'yfs:/1001/volume-01', run_as_root=True) def test_extend_volume(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_extend_volume') as mock_extend_volume: drv.extend_volume(self.volume_1, '4') mock_extend_volume.assert_called_once_with('volume-01', '4') def test_extend_volume_execute(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: drv._extend_volume(self.volume_name_1, '3') mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('qemu-img', 'resize', 'yfs:/1001/volume-01', '3G', run_as_root=True) def test_create_volume_from_snapshot(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_create_volume_from_snapshot') as \ mock_create_volume_from_snapshot: drv.create_volume_from_snapshot(self.volume_2, self.snapshot) mock_create_volume_from_snapshot.assert_called_once_with( 'volume-01', 'snapshot-01', 'volume-02') def test_create_volume_from_snapshot_execute(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: drv._create_volume_from_snapshot(self.volume_name_1, self.snapshot_name, self.volume_name_2) mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('qemu-img', 'amend', '-o', 'cmd=clone,img=' '/1001/volume-01,snap=' 'snapshot-01,trg=' '/1001/volume-02', 'yfs:/root/root', '-f', 'yfs', run_as_root=True) def test_update_volume_stats(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_get_pool_capacity_gb') as \ mock_get_pool_capacity_gb: mock_get_pool_capacity_gb.return_value = (1000, 700) drv._update_volume_stats() expected = { 'QoS_support': False, 'volume_backend_name': 'YeeSan', 'free_capacity_gb': 700, 'driver_version': '1.0.0', 'total_capacity_gb': 1000, 'pools': [ { 'pool_name': 'YeeSan', 'total_capacity_gb': 1000, 'driver_version': '1.0.0', 'reserved_percentage': '0', 'storage_protocol': 'yfs', 'free_capacity_gb': 700 }], 'vendor_name': 'Daowoo', 'reserved_percentage': '0', 'storage_protocol': 'yfs' } self.assertDictMatch(expected, drv._stats) def test_get_pool_capacity_gb(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: fake_info = '\n'.join([ '2015-06-12 15:15:19.495930 INFO - ' 'thread: 140697050507008 connect to 1, status: 0', '2015-06-12 15:15:19.696178 INFO - ' 'thread: 140697050507008 Update leader to 1', 'f_type:296', 'f_bsize:140697076328288', 'f_blocks:3424', 'f_bfree:72', 'f_bavail:140697122806192', 'f_files:140697122923168', 'f_ffree:140697122812960', 'f_namelen:72', 'f_frsize:0', ]) mock_execute.return_value = (fake_info, 0) rtn = drv._get_pool_capacity_gb() self.assertEqual(448661660, rtn[0]) self.assertEqual(9434474, rtn[1]) def test_check_valid_device(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: mock_execute.return_value = ('out', 'info') rtn = drv._check_valid_device(self.path) mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('dd', 'if=/mnt/yfs/1001/volume.vol', 'of=/dev/null', 'count=1', run_as_root=True) self.assertTrue(rtn) def test_check_valid_device_info_is_none(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: mock_execute.return_value = ('out', None) rtn = drv._check_valid_device(self.path) mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('dd', 'if=/mnt/yfs/1001/volume.vol', 'of=/dev/null', 'count=1', run_as_root=True) self.assertFalse(rtn) def test_check_valid_device_raise(self): drv = self._driver with mock.patch.object(drv, '_execute') as mock_execute: # mock_execute.return_value = ('out', 'info') mock_execute.side_effect = putils.ProcessExecutionError rtn = drv._check_valid_device(self.path) mock_execute.assert_called_once_with('dd', 'if=/mnt/yfs/1001/volume.vol', 'of=/dev/null', 'count=1', run_as_root=True) self.assertFalse(rtn)

commit_message:
Use oslo_config new type PortOpt for port options

The oslo_config library provides new type PortOpt to validate the
range of port now.

Change-Id: I08162e1657c3ec05a55289966ab6d7706370cef1
Depends-On: Ida294b05a85f5bef587b761fcd03c28c7a3474d8

commit_message:
Remove cinder's RequestBodySizeLimiter

Remove cinder.api.middleware.sizelimit:RequestBodySizeLimiter in favor
of oslo_middleware:RequestBodySizeLimiter. The former was left as a
compatibility shim for kilo, removing this for Mitaka since the
operators should have already migrated to the latter.

Change-Id: I5d8c03921146697d54330d074e4ba461168eaf94
Closes-Bug: #1499921

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Request Body limiting middleware. Compatibility shim for Kilo, while operators migrate to oslo.middleware. """ from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import versionutils from oslo_middleware import sizelimit # Default request size is 112k max_request_body_size_opt = cfg.IntOpt('osapi_max_request_body_size', default=114688, help='Max size for body of a request') CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opt(max_request_body_size_opt) @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.KILO, in_favor_of='oslo_middleware.RequestBodySizeLimiter') class RequestBodySizeLimiter(sizelimit.RequestBodySizeLimiter): """Add a 'cinder.context' to WSGI environ.""" pass

subject: WIP: RemoteFS volume format handlers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-13 17:28:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/4733c76df80016450459639df1aaf7a5c943b6d3', 'message': "WIP: RemoteFS volume format handlers

Move the code, which works with image files to separate
classes, 'image format handlers'.

These classes contain methods create_volume, delete_volume,
create_snapshot e.t.c.. Methods take one extra argument in
contrast to correspoding methods in VolumeDrive - mount_point.
It's a directory, where images should be placed.

When you create a volume driver will select proper format handler
class depeding on volume_format in volume metadata, volume type
and default config parameter (<driver prefix>_default_image_format).
volume_create will update volume metadata and store volume_format
there. So in consequent operation proper class will be selected
as specified in Volume object.

This change have 3 advantages:
1. Duplicated code from remotefs driver will be removed.
2. All drivers will support all volume formats.
3. New volume formats could be added easily, including non-qcow2
   snapshots.

I want to add new volume format
https://openvz.org/Ploop/format
https://openvz.org/Ploop/Why

This format is very different from qcow2 including snapshots, so
it's not so easy to add it with current remotefs drivers design.

Most of the volume and snapshots operations work with this patch and
nfs and vzstorage drivers. There are only 8 fails in tempest.

But, please, don't check the code very carefully, because of course,
there are problems in it. I wanted to demonstrate this approach
and discuss it.

Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder/remotefs-volume-format-handlers

Change-Id: Ia2d60156e1a82801699e16b8680f52e4d1ed0def
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-27 07:07:07.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/vzstorage.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/nfs.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/remotefs.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/80a50644795a3457cade712685a58ae81acfe299', 'message': "WIP: RemoteFS volume format handlers

This change have 3 advantages:

Change-Id: Ia2d60156e1a82801699e16b8680f52e4d1ed0def"}]
commit_message:
WIP: RemoteFS volume format handlers

Move the code, which works with image files to separate
classes, 'image format handlers'.

These classes contain methods create_volume, delete_volume,
create_snapshot e.t.c.. Methods take one extra argument in
contrast to correspoding methods in VolumeDrive - mount_point.
It's a directory, where images should be placed.

When you create a volume driver will select proper format handler
class depeding on volume_format in volume metadata, volume type
and default config parameter (<driver prefix>_default_image_format).
volume_create will update volume metadata and store volume_format
there. So in consequent operation proper class will be selected
as specified in Volume object.

This change have 3 advantages:
1. Duplicated code from remotefs driver will be removed.
2. All drivers will support all volume formats.
3. New volume formats could be added easily, including non-qcow2
   snapshots.

I want to add new volume format
https://openvz.org/Ploop/format
https://openvz.org/Ploop/Why

This format is very different from qcow2 including snapshots, so
it's not so easy to add it with current remotefs drivers design.

Most of the volume and snapshots operations work with this patch and
nfs and vzstorage drivers. There are only 8 fails in tempest.

But, please, don't check the code very carefully, because of course,
there are problems in it. I wanted to demonstrate this approach
and discuss it.

Partial-Implements: blueprint remotefs-volume-format-handlers

Change-Id: Ia2d60156e1a82801699e16b8680f52e4d1ed0def
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/59/234359/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import abcfrom cinder.objects.volume import Volume@six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class VolumeFormat(object): def __init__(self, driver_prefix, configuration, execute, execute_as_root): self.driver_prefix = driver_prefix self.configuration = configuration self._execute = execute self._execute_as_root = execute_as_root @abc.abstractmethod def create_volume(self, mount_point, volume): return @abc.abstractmethod def delete_volume(self, mount_point, volume): return @abc.abstractmethod def copy_image_to_volume(self, mount_point, context, volume, image_service, image_id): return @abc.abstractmethod def copy_volume_to_image(self, mount_point, context, volume, image_service, image_meta): return @abc.abstractmethod def get_active_image(self, mount_point, volume): return @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class SnapshotVolumeFormat(VolumeFormat): @abc.abstractmethod def create_snapshot(self, nova, mount_point, snapshot): return @abc.abstractmethod def delete_snapshot(self, nova, mount_point, snapshot): return @abc.abstractmethod def create_volume_from_snapshot(self, mount_point, volume, snapshot): return class RawVolumeFormatBase(SnapshotVolumeFormat): def _volume_file(self, volume_name): return "test-volume-%s" % volume_name def _local_path(self, mount_point, volume): return os.path.join(mount_point, self._volume_file(volume['name'])) def _delete(self, path): # Note(lpetrut): this method is needed in order to provide # interoperability with Windows as it will be overridden. self._execute('rm', '-f', path, run_as_root=self._execute_as_root) def delete_volume(self, mount_point, volume): if not volume['provider_location']: LOG.warning(_LW('Volume %s does not have ' 'provider_location specified, ' 'skipping'), volume['name']) return self._delete(self._local_path(mount_point, volume)) def copy_image_to_volume(self, mount_point, context, volume, image_service, image_id): run_as_root = self._execute_as_root volume_file = self._local_path(mount_point, volume) image_utils.fetch_to_raw(context, image_service, image_id, volume_file, self.configuration.volume_dd_blocksize, size=volume['size'], run_as_root=run_as_root) # NOTE (leseb): Set the virtual size of the image # the raw conversion overwrote the destination file # (which had the correct size) # with the fetched glance image size, # thus the initial 'size' parameter is not honored # this sets the size to the one asked in the first place by the user # and then verify the final virtual size image_utils.resize_image(volume_file, volume['size'], run_as_root=run_as_root) data = image_utils.qemu_img_info(volume_file, run_as_root=run_as_root) virt_size = data.virtual_size / units.Gi if virt_size != volume['size']: raise exception.ImageUnacceptable( image_id=image_id, reason=(_("Expected volume size was %d") % volume['size']) + (_(" but size is now %d") % virt_size)) def copy_volume_to_image(self, mount_point, context, volume, image_service, image_meta): image_utils.upload_volume(context, image_service, image_meta, self._local_path(mount_point, volume)) def _local_path_volume(self, mount_point, volume): return self._local_path(mount_point, volume) def _get_new_snap_path(self, mount_point, snapshot): vol_path = self._local_path(mount_point, snapshot['volume']) snap_path = '%s.%s' % (vol_path, snapshot['id']) return snap_path def _local_path_volume_info(self, mount_point, volume): return '%s%s' % (self._local_path(mount_point, volume), '.info') def _read_file(self, filename): """This method is to make it easier to stub out code for testing. Returns a string representing the contents of the file. """ with open(filename, 'r') as f: return f.read() def _write_info_file(self, info_path, snap_info): if 'active' not in snap_info.keys(): msg = _("'active' must be present when writing snap_info.") raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) with open(info_path, 'w') as f: json.dump(snap_info, f, indent=1, sort_keys=True) def _qemu_img_info(self, path, volume_name, mount_point): """Sanitize image_utils' qemu_img_info. This code expects to deal only with relative filenames. """ info = image_utils.qemu_img_info(path) if info.image: info.image = os.path.basename(info.image) if info.backing_file: backing_file_template = \ "(%(mount_point)s/)?%" \ "(volume_file)s(.(tmp-snap-)?[0-9a-f-]+)?$" % { 'mount_point': mount_point, 'volume_file': self._volume_file(volume_name) } if not re.match(backing_file_template, info.backing_file): msg = _("File %(path)s has invalid backing file " "%(bfile)s, aborting.") % {'path': path, 'bfile': info.backing_file} raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) info.backing_file = os.path.basename(info.backing_file) return info def _img_commit(self, path): self._execute('qemu-img', 'commit', path, run_as_root=self._execute_as_root) self._delete(path) def _rebase_img(self, image, backing_file, volume_format): self._execute('qemu-img', 'rebase', '-u', '-b', backing_file, image, '-F', volume_format, run_as_root=self._execute_as_root) def _read_info_file(self, info_path, empty_if_missing=False): """Return dict of snapshot information. :param: info_path: path to file :param: empty_if_missing: True=return empty dict if no file """ if not os.path.exists(info_path): if empty_if_missing is True: return {} return json.loads(self._read_file(info_path)) def _get_backing_chain_for_path(self, volume, path, mount_point): """Returns list of dicts containing backing-chain information. Includes 'filename', and 'backing-filename' for each applicable entry. Consider converting this to use --backing-chain and --output=json when environment supports qemu-img 1.5.0. :param volume: volume reference :param path: path to image file at top of chain """ output = [] info = self._qemu_img_info(path, volume['name'], mount_point) new_info = {} new_info['filename'] = os.path.basename(path) new_info['backing-filename'] = info.backing_file output.append(new_info) while new_info['backing-filename']: filename = new_info['backing-filename'] path = os.path.join(mount_point, filename) info = self._qemu_img_info(path, volume['name'], mount_point) backing_filename = info.backing_file new_info = {} new_info['filename'] = filename new_info['backing-filename'] = backing_filename output.append(new_info) return output def _do_create_snapshot(self, mount_point, snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path): """Create a QCOW2 file backed by another file. :param snapshot: snapshot reference :param backing_filename: filename of file that will back the new qcow2 file :param new_snap_path: filename of new qcow2 file """ backing_path_full_path = os.path.join(mount_point, backing_filename) command = ['qemu-img', 'create', '-f', 'qcow2', '-o', 'backing_file=%s' % backing_path_full_path, new_snap_path] self._execute(*command, run_as_root=self._execute_as_root) info = self._qemu_img_info(backing_path_full_path, snapshot['volume']['name'], mount_point) backing_fmt = info.file_format command = ['qemu-img', 'rebase', '-u', '-b', backing_filename, '-F', backing_fmt, new_snap_path] self._execute(*command, run_as_root=self._execute_as_root) # self._set_rw_permissions(new_snap_path) def create_snapshot(self, nova, mount_point, snapshot): """Create a snapshot. If volume is attached, call to Nova to create snapshot, providing a qcow2 file. Cinder creates and deletes qcow2 files, but Nova is responsible for transitioning the VM between them and handling live transfers of data between files as required. If volume is detached, create locally with qemu-img. Cinder handles manipulation of qcow2 files. A file named volume-<uuid>.info is stored with the volume data and is a JSON table which contains a mapping between Cinder snapshot UUIDs and filenames, as these associations will change as snapshots are deleted. Basic snapshot operation: 1. Initial volume file: volume-1234 2. Snapshot created: volume-1234 <- volume-1234.aaaa volume-1234.aaaa becomes the new "active" disk image. If the volume is not attached, this filename will be used to attach the volume to a VM at volume-attach time. If the volume is attached, the VM will switch to this file as part of the snapshot process. Note that volume-1234.aaaa represents changes after snapshot 'aaaa' was created. So the data for snapshot 'aaaa' is actually in the backing file(s) of volume-1234.aaaa. This file has a qcow2 header recording the fact that volume-1234 is its backing file. Delta changes since the snapshot was created are stored in this file, and the backing file (volume-1234) does not change. info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.aaaa', 'aaaa': 'volume-1234.aaaa' } 3. Second snapshot created: volume-1234 <- volume-1234.aaaa <- volume-1234.bbbb volume-1234.bbbb now becomes the "active" disk image, recording changes made to the volume. info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.bbbb', (* changed!) 'aaaa': 'volume-1234.aaaa', 'bbbb': 'volume-1234.bbbb' } (* added!) 4. Snapshot deletion when volume is attached ('in-use' state): * When first snapshot is deleted, Cinder calls Nova for online snapshot deletion. Nova deletes snapshot with id "aaaa" and makes snapshot with id "bbbb" point to the base image. Snapshot with id "bbbb" is the active image. volume-1234 <- volume-1234.bbbb info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.bbbb', 'bbbb': 'volume-1234.bbbb' } * When second snapshot is deleted, Cinder calls Nova for online snapshot deletion. Nova deletes snapshot with id "bbbb" by pulling volume-1234's data into volume-1234.bbbb. This (logically) removes snapshot with id "bbbb" and the active file remains the same. volume-1234.bbbb info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.bbbb' } TODO (deepakcs): Change this once Nova supports blockCommit for in-use volumes. 5. Snapshot deletion when volume is detached ('available' state): * When first snapshot is deleted, Cinder does the snapshot deletion. volume-1234.aaaa is removed from the snapshot chain. The data from it is merged into its parent. volume-1234.bbbb is rebased, having volume-1234 as its new parent. volume-1234 <- volume-1234.bbbb info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.bbbb', 'bbbb': 'volume-1234.bbbb' } * When second snapshot is deleted, Cinder does the snapshot deletion. volume-1234.aaaa is removed from the snapshot chain. The base image, volume-1234 becomes the active image for this volume again. volume-1234 info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234' } (* changed!) """ volume = snapshot['volume'] status = volume['status'] if status not in ['available', 'in-use']: msg = _('Volume status must be "available" or "in-use"' ' for snapshot. (is %s)') % status raise exception.InvalidVolume(msg) info_path = self._local_path_volume_info(mount_point, volume) snap_info = self._read_info_file(info_path, empty_if_missing=True) backing_filename = self._get_active_image_from_info(mount_point, volume) new_snap_path = self._get_new_snap_path(mount_point, snapshot) if status == 'in-use': self._create_snapshot_online(nova, mount_point, snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path) else: self._do_create_snapshot(mount_point, snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path) snap_info['active'] = os.path.basename(new_snap_path) snap_info[snapshot['id']] = os.path.basename(new_snap_path) self._write_info_file(info_path, snap_info) def _create_snapshot_online(self, nova, mount_point, snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path): # Perform online snapshot via Nova context = snapshot['context'] self._do_create_snapshot(mount_point, snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path) connection_info = { 'type': 'qcow2', 'new_file': os.path.basename(new_snap_path), 'snapshot_id': snapshot['id'] } try: result = nova.create_volume_snapshot( context, snapshot['volume_id'], connection_info) LOG.debug('nova call result: %s', result) except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE('Call to Nova to create snapshot failed')) raise # Loop and wait for result # Nova will call Cinderclient to update the status in the database # An update of progress = '90%' means that Nova is done seconds_elapsed = 0 increment = 1 timeout = 600 while True: s = db.snapshot_get(context, snapshot['id']) if s['status'] == 'creating': if s['progress'] == '90%': # Nova tasks completed successfully break time.sleep(increment) seconds_elapsed += increment elif s['status'] == 'error': msg = _('Nova returned "error" status ' 'while creating snapshot.') raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) LOG.debug('Status of snapshot %(id)s is now %(status)s', {'id': snapshot['id'], 'status': s['status']}) if 10 < seconds_elapsed <= 20: increment = 2 elif 20 < seconds_elapsed <= 60: increment = 5 elif 60 < seconds_elapsed: increment = 10 if seconds_elapsed > timeout: msg = _('Timed out while waiting for Nova update ' 'for creation of snapshot %s.') % snapshot['id'] raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) def _delete_stale_snapshot(self, mount_point, snapshot): volume = snapshot['volume'] info_path = self._local_path_volume_info(mount_point, volume) snap_info = self._read_info_file(info_path) snapshot_file = snap_info[snapshot['id']] active_file = self._get_active_image_from_info(mount_point, volume) snapshot_path = os.path.join(mount_point, snapshot_file) if (snapshot_file == active_file): return LOG.info(_LI('Deleting stale snapshot: %s'), snapshot['id']) self._delete(snapshot_path) del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) self._write_info_file(info_path, snap_info) def delete_snapshot(self, nova, mount_point, snapshot): """Delete a snapshot. If volume status is 'available', delete snapshot here in Cinder using qemu-img. If volume status is 'in-use', calculate what qcow2 files need to merge, and call to Nova to perform this operation. :raises: InvalidVolume if status not acceptable :raises: RemoteFSException(msg) if operation fails :returns: None """ LOG.debug('Deleting snapshot %s:', snapshot['id']) volume = snapshot['volume'] volume_status = volume['status'] if volume_status not in ['available', 'in-use']: msg = _('Volume status must be "available" or "in-use".') raise exception.InvalidVolume(msg) # Determine the true snapshot file for this snapshot # based on the .info file info_path = self._local_path_volume_info(mount_point, volume) snap_info = self._read_info_file(info_path, empty_if_missing=True) if snapshot['id'] not in snap_info: # If snapshot info file is present, but snapshot record does not # exist, do not attempt to delete. # (This happens, for example, if snapshot_create failed due to lack # of permission to write to the share.) LOG.info(_LI('Snapshot record for %s is not present, allowing ' 'snapshot_delete to proceed.'), snapshot['id']) return snapshot_file = snap_info[snapshot['id']] LOG.debug('snapshot_file for this snap is: %s', snapshot_file) snapshot_path = os.path.join(mount_point, snapshot_file) snapshot_path_img_info = self._qemu_img_info( snapshot_path, volume['name'], mount_point) base_file = snapshot_path_img_info.backing_file if base_file is None: # There should always be at least the original volume # file as base. LOG.warning(_LW('No backing file found for %s, allowing ' 'snapshot to be deleted.'), snapshot_path) # Snapshot may be stale, so just delete it and update the # info file instead of blocking return self._delete_stale_snapshot(snapshot) base_path = os.path.join(mount_point, base_file) base_file_img_info = self._qemu_img_info(base_path, volume['name'], mount_point) # Find what file has this as its backing file active_file = self._get_active_image_from_info(mount_point, volume) active_file_path = os.path.join(mount_point, active_file) if volume_status == 'in-use': # Online delete context = snapshot['context'] new_base_file = base_file_img_info.backing_file base_id = None for key, value in snap_info.items(): if value == base_file and key != 'active': base_id = key break if base_id is None: # This means we are deleting the oldest snapshot LOG.debug('No %(base_id)s found for %(file)s', {'base_id': 'base_id', 'file': snapshot_file}) online_delete_info = { 'active_file': active_file, 'snapshot_file': snapshot_file, 'base_file': base_file, 'base_id': base_id, 'new_base_file': new_base_file } return self._delete_snapshot_online(nova, context, snapshot, online_delete_info) if snapshot_file == active_file: # There is no top file # T0 | T1 | # base | snapshot_file | None # (guaranteed to| (being deleted, | # exist) | commited down) | self._img_commit(snapshot_path) # Active file has changed snap_info['active'] = base_file else: # T0 | T1 | T2 | T3 # base | snapshot_file | higher_file | highest_file # (guaranteed to | (being deleted, | (guaranteed to | (may exist) # exist, not | commited down) | exist, needs | # used here) | | ptr update) | backing_chain = self._get_backing_chain_for_path( volume, active_file_path) # This file is guaranteed to exist since we aren't operating on # the active file. higher_file = next((os.path.basename(f['filename']) for f in backing_chain if f.get('backing-filename', '') == snapshot_file), None) if higher_file is None: msg = _('No file found with %s as backing file.') %\ snapshot_file raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) higher_id = next((i for i in snap_info if snap_info[i] == higher_file and i != 'active'), None) if higher_id is None: msg = _('No snap found with %s as backing file.') %\ higher_file raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) self._img_commit(snapshot_path) higher_file_path = os.path.join(mount_point, higher_file) base_file_fmt = base_file_img_info.file_format self._rebase_img(higher_file_path, base_file, base_file_fmt) # Remove snapshot_file from info del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) self._write_info_file(info_path, snap_info) def _delete_snapshot_online(self, nova, mount_point, context, snapshot, info): # Update info over the course of this method # active file never changes info_path = self._local_path_volume(snapshot['volume']) + '.info' snap_info = self._read_info_file(info_path) if info['active_file'] == info['snapshot_file']: # blockRebase/Pull base into active # info['base'] => snapshot_file file_to_delete = info['base_file'] if info['base_id'] is None: # Passing base=none to blockRebase ensures that # libvirt blanks out the qcow2 backing file pointer new_base = None else: new_base = info['new_base_file'] snap_info[info['base_id']] = info['snapshot_file'] delete_info = {'file_to_merge': new_base, 'merge_target_file': None, # current 'type': 'qcow2', 'volume_id': snapshot['volume']['id']} del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) else: # blockCommit snapshot into base # info['base'] <= snapshot_file # delete record of snapshot file_to_delete = info['snapshot_file'] delete_info = {'file_to_merge': info['snapshot_file'], 'merge_target_file': info['base_file'], 'type': 'qcow2', 'volume_id': snapshot['volume']['id']} del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) try: nova.delete_volume_snapshot( context, snapshot['id'], delete_info) except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE('Call to Nova delete snapshot failed')) raise # Loop and wait for result # Nova will call Cinderclient to update the status in the database # An update of progress = '90%' means that Nova is done seconds_elapsed = 0 increment = 1 timeout = 7200 while True: s = db.snapshot_get(context, snapshot['id']) if s['status'] == 'deleting': if s['progress'] == '90%': # Nova tasks completed successfully break else: LOG.debug('status of snapshot %s is still "deleting"... ' 'waiting', snapshot['id']) time.sleep(increment) seconds_elapsed += increment else: msg = _('Unable to delete snapshot %(id)s, ' 'status: %(status)s.') % {'id': snapshot['id'], 'status': s['status']} raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) if 10 < seconds_elapsed <= 20: increment = 2 elif 20 < seconds_elapsed <= 60: increment = 5 elif 60 < seconds_elapsed: increment = 10 if seconds_elapsed > timeout: msg = _('Timed out while waiting for Nova update ' 'for deletion of snapshot %(id)s.') %\ {'id': snapshot['id']} raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) # Write info file updated above self._write_info_file(info_path, snap_info) # Delete stale file path_to_delete = os.path.join(mount_point, file_to_delete) self._execute('rm', '-f', path_to_delete, run_as_root=True) def _get_active_image_from_info(self, mount_point, volume): """Returns filename of the active image from the info file.""" info_file = self._local_path_volume_info(mount_point, volume) snap_info = self._read_info_file(info_file, empty_if_missing=True) if not snap_info: # No info file = no snapshots exist vol_path = os.path.basename(self._local_path(mount_point, volume)) return vol_path return snap_info['active'] def _create_cloned_volume(self, mount_point, volume, src_vref): LOG.info(_LI('Cloning volume %(src)s to volume %(dst)s'), {'src': src_vref['id'], 'dst': volume['id']}) if src_vref['status'] != 'available': msg = _("Volume status must be 'available'.") raise exception.InvalidVolume(msg) volume_name = CONF.volume_name_template % volume['id'] volume_info = {'provider_location': src_vref['provider_location'], 'size': src_vref['size'], 'id': volume['id'], 'name': volume_name, 'status': src_vref['status']} temp_snapshot = {'volume_name': volume_name, 'size': src_vref['size'], 'volume_size': src_vref['size'], 'name': 'clone-snap-%s' % src_vref['id'], 'volume_id': src_vref['id'], 'id': 'tmp-snap-%s' % src_vref['id'], 'volume': src_vref} self._create_snapshot(temp_snapshot) try: self._copy_volume_from_snapshot(mount_point, temp_snapshot, volume_info, volume['size']) finally: self._delete_snapshot(temp_snapshot) return {'provider_location': src_vref['provider_location']} def create_volume_from_snapshot(self, mount_point, volume, snapshot): """Creates a volume from a snapshot. Snapshot must not be the active snapshot. (offline) """ if snapshot['status'] != 'available': msg = _('Snapshot status must be "available" to clone.') raise exception.InvalidSnapshot(msg) self.create_volume(mount_point, volume) self._copy_volume_from_snapshot(mount_point, snapshot, volume, volume['size']) return {'provider_location': volume['provider_location']} def _copy_volume_from_snapshot(self, mount_point, snapshot, volume, volume_size): LOG.debug("Snapshot: %(snap)s, volume: %(vol)s, " "volume_size: %(size)s", {'snap': snapshot['id'], 'vol': volume['id'], 'size': volume_size}) volume = snapshot['volume'] info_path = self._local_path_volume_info(mount_point, volume) snap_info = self._read_info_file(info_path) out_format = "qcow2" forward_file = snap_info[snapshot['id']] forward_path = os.path.join(mount_point, forward_file) # Find the file which backs this file, which represents the point # when this snapshot was created. img_info = self._qemu_img_info(forward_path, volume['name'], mount_point) path_to_snap_img = os.path.join(mount_point, img_info.backing_file) LOG.debug("Will copy from snapshot at %s", path_to_snap_img) image_utils.convert_image(path_to_snap_img, self._local_path(mount_point, volume), out_format) self.extend_volume(mount_point, volume, volume_size) # self._set_rw_permissions_for_all(self.local_path(volume)) def _copy_volume_to_image(self, mount_point, context, volume, image_service, image_meta): """Copy the volume to the specified image.""" # If snapshots exist, flatten to a temporary image, and upload it active_file = self._get_active_image_from_info(volume) active_file_path = os.path.join(mount_point, active_file) info = self._qemu_img_info(active_file_path, volume['name'], mount_point) backing_file = info.backing_file root_file_fmt = info.file_format tmp_params = { 'prefix': '%s.temp_image.%s' % (volume['id'], image_meta['id']), 'suffix': '.img' } with image_utils.temporary_file(**tmp_params) as temp_path: if backing_file or (root_file_fmt != 'raw'): # Convert due to snapshots # or volume data not being stored in raw format # (upload_volume assumes raw format input) image_utils.convert_image(active_file_path, temp_path, 'raw') upload_path = temp_path else: upload_path = active_file_path image_utils.upload_volume(context, image_service, image_meta, upload_path) def get_active_image(self, mount_point, volume): return self._get_active_image_from_info(mount_point, volume), "raw" def extend_volume(self, mount_point, volume, size_gb): volume_path = self._local_path(mount_point, volume) self._check_extend_volume_support(mount_point, volume, size_gb) LOG.info(_LI('Resizing file to %sG...'), size_gb) self._do_extend_volume(mount_point, volume_path, size_gb, volume['name']) def _do_extend_volume(self, mount_point, volume_path, size_gb, volume_name): image_utils.resize_image(volume_path, size_gb) if not self._is_file_size_equal(volume_path, size_gb): raise exception.ExtendVolumeError( reason='Resizing image file failed.') def _check_extend_volume_support(self, mount_point, volume, size_gb): volume_path = self._local_path(mount_point, volume) active_file = self._get_active_image_from_info(mount_point, volume) active_file_path = os.path.join(mount_point, active_file) if active_file_path != volume_path: msg = _('Extend volume is only supported for this ' 'driver when no snapshots exist.') raise exception.InvalidVolume(msg) def _is_file_size_equal(self, path, size): """Checks if file size at path is equal to size.""" data = image_utils.qemu_img_info(path) virt_size = data.virtual_size / units.Gi return virt_size == size class RawVolumeFormat(RawVolumeFormatBase): name = "raw" def create_volume(self, mount_point, volume): block_size_mb = 1 block_count = volume['size'] * units.Gi / (block_size_mb * units.Mi) image_path = self._local_path(mount_point, volume) self._execute('dd', 'if=/dev/zero', 'of=%s' % image_path, If volume is attached, call to Nova to create snapshot, providing a qcow2 file. Cinder creates and deletes qcow2 files, but Nova is responsible for transitioning the VM between them and handling live transfers of data between files as required. If volume is detached, create locally with qemu-img. Cinder handles manipulation of qcow2 files. A file named volume-<uuid>.info is stored with the volume data and is a JSON table which contains a mapping between Cinder snapshot UUIDs and filenames, as these associations will change as snapshots are deleted. Basic snapshot operation: 1. Initial volume file: volume-1234 2. Snapshot created: volume-1234 <- volume-1234.aaaa volume-1234.aaaa becomes the new "active" disk image. If the volume is not attached, this filename will be used to attach the volume to a VM at volume-attach time. If the volume is attached, the VM will switch to this file as part of the snapshot process. Note that volume-1234.aaaa represents changes after snapshot 'aaaa' was created. So the data for snapshot 'aaaa' is actually in the backing file(s) of volume-1234.aaaa. This file has a qcow2 header recording the fact that volume-1234 is its backing file. Delta changes since the snapshot was created are stored in this file, and the backing file (volume-1234) does not change. info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.aaaa', 'aaaa': 'volume-1234.aaaa' } 3. Second snapshot created: volume-1234 <- volume-1234.aaaa <- volume-1234.bbbb volume-1234.bbbb now becomes the "active" disk image, recording changes made to the volume. info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.bbbb', (* changed!) 'aaaa': 'volume-1234.aaaa', 'bbbb': 'volume-1234.bbbb' } (* added!) 4. Snapshot deletion when volume is attached ('in-use' state): * When first snapshot is deleted, Cinder calls Nova for online snapshot deletion. Nova deletes snapshot with id "aaaa" and makes snapshot with id "bbbb" point to the base image. Snapshot with id "bbbb" is the active image. volume-1234 <- volume-1234.bbbb info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.bbbb', 'bbbb': 'volume-1234.bbbb' } * When second snapshot is deleted, Cinder calls Nova for online snapshot deletion. Nova deletes snapshot with id "bbbb" by pulling volume-1234's data into volume-1234.bbbb. This (logically) removes snapshot with id "bbbb" and the active file remains the same. volume-1234.bbbb info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.bbbb' } TODO (deepakcs): Change this once Nova supports blockCommit for in-use volumes. 5. Snapshot deletion when volume is detached ('available' state): * When first snapshot is deleted, Cinder does the snapshot deletion. volume-1234.aaaa is removed from the snapshot chain. The data from it is merged into its parent. volume-1234.bbbb is rebased, having volume-1234 as its new parent. volume-1234 <- volume-1234.bbbb info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234.bbbb', 'bbbb': 'volume-1234.bbbb' } * When second snapshot is deleted, Cinder does the snapshot deletion. volume-1234.aaaa is removed from the snapshot chain. The base image, volume-1234 becomes the active image for this volume again. volume-1234 info file: { 'active': 'volume-1234' } (* changed!) """ status = snapshot['volume']['status'] if status not in ['available', 'in-use']: msg = _('Volume status must be "available" or "in-use"' ' for snapshot. (is %s)') % status raise exception.InvalidVolume(msg) info_path = self._local_path_volume_info(snapshot['volume']) snap_info = self._read_info_file(info_path, empty_if_missing=True) backing_filename = self.get_active_image_from_info( snapshot['volume']) new_snap_path = self._get_new_snap_path(snapshot) if status == 'in-use': self._create_snapshot_online(snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path) else: self._do_create_snapshot(snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path) snap_info['active'] = os.path.basename(new_snap_path) snap_info[snapshot['id']] = os.path.basename(new_snap_path) self._write_info_file(info_path, snap_info) def _create_snapshot_online(self, snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path): # Perform online snapshot via Nova context = snapshot['context'] self._do_create_snapshot(snapshot, backing_filename, new_snap_path) connection_info = { 'type': 'qcow2', 'new_file': os.path.basename(new_snap_path), 'snapshot_id': snapshot['id'] } try: result = self._nova.create_volume_snapshot( context, snapshot['volume_id'], connection_info) LOG.debug('nova call result: %s', result) except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE('Call to Nova to create snapshot failed')) raise # Loop and wait for result # Nova will call Cinderclient to update the status in the database # An update of progress = '90%' means that Nova is done seconds_elapsed = 0 increment = 1 timeout = 600 while True: s = db.snapshot_get(context, snapshot['id']) if s['status'] == 'creating': if s['progress'] == '90%': # Nova tasks completed successfully break time.sleep(increment) seconds_elapsed += increment elif s['status'] == 'error': msg = _('Nova returned "error" status ' 'while creating snapshot.') raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) LOG.debug('Status of snapshot %(id)s is now %(status)s', {'id': snapshot['id'], 'status': s['status']}) if 10 < seconds_elapsed <= 20: increment = 2 elif 20 < seconds_elapsed <= 60: increment = 5 elif 60 < seconds_elapsed: increment = 10 if seconds_elapsed > timeout: msg = _('Timed out while waiting for Nova update ' 'for creation of snapshot %s.') % snapshot['id'] raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) def _delete_snapshot_online(self, context, snapshot, info): # Update info over the course of this method # active file never changes info_path = self._local_path_volume(snapshot['volume']) + '.info' snap_info = self._read_info_file(info_path) if info['active_file'] == info['snapshot_file']: # blockRebase/Pull base into active # info['base'] => snapshot_file file_to_delete = info['base_file'] if info['base_id'] is None: # Passing base=none to blockRebase ensures that # libvirt blanks out the qcow2 backing file pointer new_base = None else: new_base = info['new_base_file'] snap_info[info['base_id']] = info['snapshot_file'] delete_info = {'file_to_merge': new_base, 'merge_target_file': None, # current 'type': 'qcow2', 'volume_id': snapshot['volume']['id']} del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) else: # blockCommit snapshot into base # info['base'] <= snapshot_file # delete record of snapshot file_to_delete = info['snapshot_file'] delete_info = {'file_to_merge': info['snapshot_file'], 'merge_target_file': info['base_file'], 'type': 'qcow2', 'volume_id': snapshot['volume']['id']} del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) try: self._nova.delete_volume_snapshot( context, snapshot['id'], delete_info) except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE('Call to Nova delete snapshot failed')) raise # Loop and wait for result # Nova will call Cinderclient to update the status in the database # An update of progress = '90%' means that Nova is done seconds_elapsed = 0 increment = 1 timeout = 7200 while True: s = db.snapshot_get(context, snapshot['id']) if s['status'] == 'deleting': if s['progress'] == '90%': # Nova tasks completed successfully break else: LOG.debug('status of snapshot %s is still "deleting"... ' 'waiting', snapshot['id']) time.sleep(increment) seconds_elapsed += increment else: msg = _('Unable to delete snapshot %(id)s, ' 'status: %(status)s.') % {'id': snapshot['id'], 'status': s['status']} raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) if 10 < seconds_elapsed <= 20: increment = 2 elif 20 < seconds_elapsed <= 60: increment = 5 elif 60 < seconds_elapsed: increment = 10 if seconds_elapsed > timeout: msg = _('Timed out while waiting for Nova update ' 'for deletion of snapshot %(id)s.') %\ {'id': snapshot['id']} raise exception.RemoteFSException(msg) # Write info file updated above self._write_info_file(info_path, snap_info) # Delete stale file path_to_delete = os.path.join( self._local_volume_dir(snapshot['volume']), file_to_delete) self._execute('rm', '-f', path_to_delete, run_as_root=True) return self._create_snapshot(snapshot) return self._delete_snapshot(snapshot) return self._create_volume_from_snapshot(volume, snapshot) def copy_volume_to_image(self, context, volume, image_service, image_meta): """Copy the volume to the specified image.""" return self._copy_volume_to_image(context, volume, image_service, image_meta)

commit_message:
Fix naming convention deviations in cinder db api

When the db model has a table named FooBar (in camel case), then the
db api methods dealing with this model element should start with the
prefix foo_bar_ (in snake case).

This convention is violated by methods dealing with ConsistencyGroup
model element where the api methods have the prefix consistencygroup_
instead of consistency_group_. Similarly, methods dealing with
VolumeTypes model element also are inconsistent since they use the
prefix volume_type_ instead of volume_types_.

These deviations make it impossible to automatically select the get
method for an ORM model.

Change-Id: Ifa7e8447d1b54d70609efe87218b4df608b5b106
Closes-Bug: #1493114

commit_message:
Fixes delete cgsnapshot to catch SnapshotIsBusy

If the driver raises SnapshotIsBusy, delete_cgsnapshot should honor
it and not place the cgsnapshot in error_deleting state. Instead,
it should keep the cgsnapshot in an available state, and simply
refuse to delete the cgsnapshot. This functionality now mirrors
delete_snapshot.

Change-Id: I39222f76f287221793d189ee5d4fe8d2fbf42704
Closes-Bug: #1488584

commit_message:
Status error after manage a volume

When we import a volume using a wrong backend,
the volume status is not 'error' but 'creating'.
This is due to a small coding error.

The parameter 'request_spec' is:
request_spec: {
	u'volume_properties': {
		u'status': u'creating',
		u'volume_type_id': None,
		u'display_name': u'liu111',
		u'availability_zone': u'nova',
		u'bootable': False,
		u'size': 0,
		u'attach_status': u'detached',
		u'display_description': None,
		u'host': u'ubuntu-204@v3r3#StoragePool001',
		u'volume_metadata': [],
		u'volume_admin_metadata': [],
		u'user_id': u'024c10bcc37142d2ab3e9ccd152ac66d',
		u'project_id': u'cddc11d599794a618ef769b8e9092f27',
		u'id': u'732953e0-8879-4a73-9af5-f96aae8ad55d',
		u'metadata': None
	},
	u'ref': {
		u'source-name': u'bc'
	},
	u'volume_type': {
		
	}
}
And there is no 'volume_id' in it.

Change-Id: I613218fbdbec9e607a920c6f5e2a9181de83165c
Closes-Bug: #1517337

commit_message:
[WIP] Robustify writing iscsi target persistence file

With the current code, it's possible to end up with a zero-size
persistence file (or even corruption of the contents) if the
process gets killed or the system takes a power outage.

Switch to a "write to temp file and rename" model for writing the
persistence file.  This will make it more robust against unclean
process termination or unclean system shutdown.

Change-Id: I5e970def35c35aee22bda1cd95507781e97eeac8
Closes-Bug: #1499795

added_lines: import tempfile dirfd = None try: dirfd = os.open(volumes_dir, os.O_DIRECTORY) # write data to temporary file with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(prefix=vol_id, dir=volumes_dir, delete=False) as tf: tempname = tf.name tf.write(volume_conf) tf.flush() os.fdatasync(tf.fileno()) # Fsync the directory to ensure the fact of the existence of # the temp file hits the disk. os.fsync(dirfd) os.rename(tempname, vol_id) # Fsync the directory to ensure the rename hits the disk. os.fsync(dirfd) except OSError as e: LOG.debug('Exception writing persistence file: %s', e) os.unlink(tempname) finally: if dirfd: os.close(dirfd)

commit_message:
Cinder part of volume snapshot improvements

This patch implements blueprint assisted-snapshot-improvements

  1) Add processing to update_snapshot_status API for new fields
  2) Add new fields to the update_snapshot_status call made by Nova
  4) Add support for compatibility with pre-liberty Nova
  5) Add testcases
  6) Fixed test_glusterfs testcases that were failing due to changes
     in remotefs code by this patch
  7) Refactored _delete_snapshot_online into pre, do and post steps

Testing Info:
  1) Tested against Nova patch (see Depends-On below)
     using GlusterFS as the Cinder backend

Implements: blueprint assisted-snapshot-improvements
Depends-On: Ib5c3de6e757a8cdd098d68ca26194891458b57a9
Change-Id: Ifa2836a87271d465af61c4ae4b2018cde0698924

added_lines: snapshot_file_fmt = snapshot_path_img_info.file_format base_file_fmt = base_file_img_info.file_format base_of_base_file = base_file_img_info.backing_file if base_of_base_file is not None: base_of_base_path = os.path.join( self._local_volume_dir(snapshot['volume']), base_of_base_file) base_of_base_file_img_info = self._qemu_img_info( base_of_base_path, snapshot['volume']['name']) base_of_base_file_fmt = base_of_base_file_img_info.file_format else: base_of_base_file_fmt = None 'snapshot_file_fmt': snapshot_file_fmt, 'base_file_fmt': base_file_fmt, # FIXME: Remove base_id once api layer updates file_to_delete in DB 'base_of_base_file': base_of_base_file, 'base_of_base_file_fmt': base_of_base_file_fmt # FIXME: Derive snap_info entry to be overwritten from DB once api layer updates file_to_delete in DB if info['active_file'] == info['snapshot_file']: if info['base_id'] is not None: del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) info['type'] = 'qcow2' info['volume_id'] = snapshot['volume']['id'] info) # TODO: Commented until file_to_delete is available from DB # path_to_delete = os.path.join( # self._local_volume_dir(snapshot['volume']), file_to_delete) # self._execute('rm', '-f', path_to_delete, run_as_root=True)
deleted_lines: new_base_file = base_file_img_info.backing_file 'new_base_file': new_base_file if info['active_file'] == info['snapshot_file']: # blockRebase/Pull base into active # info['base'] => snapshot_file file_to_delete = info['base_file'] if info['base_id'] is None: # Passing base=none to blockRebase ensures that # libvirt blanks out the qcow2 backing file pointer new_base = None else: new_base = info['new_base_file'] delete_info = {'file_to_merge': new_base, 'merge_target_file': None, # current 'type': 'qcow2', 'volume_id': snapshot['volume']['id']} del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) else: # blockCommit snapshot into base # info['base'] <= snapshot_file # delete record of snapshot file_to_delete = info['snapshot_file'] delete_info = {'file_to_merge': info['snapshot_file'], 'merge_target_file': info['base_file'], 'type': 'qcow2', 'volume_id': snapshot['volume']['id']} del(snap_info[snapshot['id']]) delete_info) path_to_delete = os.path.join( self._local_volume_dir(snapshot['volume']), file_to_delete) self._execute('rm', '-f', path_to_delete, run_as_root=True)

commit_message:
Fake driver is added to test large_ops

This driver has capabilty to add/delete volumes, sanpshots etc.
It will not create the actual volume. It will just save data
in data structure.

Change-Id: If0e42ce057266868188389ec44379204e69750a0
Closes-Bug: #1250696
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/13/224413/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from cinder import exception from cinder.i18n import _, _LI from cinder import objects from cinder.volume import driver from oslo_log import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class VolumeInstance(object): def __init__(self, name, size): self.name = name self.size = size class ConsistencyGroup(object): def __init__(self, name): self.name = name self.volume_list = {} def add_volume_to_group(self, volume): self.volume_list[volume.name] = volume def delete_volume_from_group(self, volume): del self.volume_list[volume.name] class FakeApi(object): def __init__(self): self.volumes = {} self.consistency_groups = {} pass def create_volume(self, name, size): self.volumes[name] = VolumeInstance(name, size) def delete_volume(self, name): del self.volumes[name] def find_volume(self, name): if name in self.volumes: return self.volumes[name] return None def update_volume(self, volume_name, new_size): self.volumes[volume_name].size = new_size def create_consistency_group(self, name): self.consistency_groups[name] = ConsistencyGroup(name) def delete_consistency_group(self, name): del self.consistency_groups[name] def find_consistency_group(self, name): if name in self.consistency_groups: return self.consistency_groups[name] return None class FakeVolumeDriver(driver.ConsistencyGroupVD, driver.ManageableVD, driver.ExtendVD, driver.CloneableVD, driver.SnapshotVD, driver.BaseVD): def do_setup(self, context): self.api_client = FakeApi() def create_volume(self, volume): volume_name = volume.get('id') volume_size = volume.get('size') LOG.debug('Creating volume %(name)s of size %(size)s', {'name': volume_name, 'size': volume_size}) self.api_client.create_volume(volume_name, volume_size) def check_for_setup_error(self): pass def create_volume_from_snapshot(self, volume, snapshot): snapshot_id = snapshot.get('cgsnapshot_id') if not snapshot_id: snapshot_id = snapshot.get('id') volume_name = volume.get('id') volume_size = volume.get('volume_size') LOG.debug( 'Creating new volume %(vol)s from snapshot %(snap)s ' 'from vol %(src)s', {'vol': volume_name, 'snap': snapshot_id}) LOG.debug('snapshot %(snap)', {'snap': snapshot}) self.api_client.create_volume(volume_name, volume_size) def create_cloned_volume(self, volume, src_vref): pass def delete_volume(self, volume): volume_name = volume.get('id') LOG.debug('Deleting volume %s', volume_name) self.api_client.delete_volume(volume_name) def create_snapshot(self, snapshot): volume_name = snapshot.get('volume_id') snapshot_id = snapshot.get('id') LOG.debug('Creating snapshot %(snap)s on volume %(vol)s', {'snap': snapshot_id, 'vol': volume_name}) snapshot['status'] = 'available' return def delete_snapshot(self, snapshot): volume_name = snapshot.get('volume_id') snapshot_id = snapshot.get('id') LOG.debug('Deleting snapshot %(snap)s from volume %(vol)s', {'snap': snapshot_id, 'vol': volume_name}) return def extend_volume(self, volume, new_size): volume_name = volume.get('id') LOG.debug('Extending volume %(vol)s to %(size)s', {'vol': volume_name, 'size': new_size}) if self.api_client.find_volume(volume_name): self.api_client.update_volume(volume_name, new_size) return raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException( _('Unable to extend volume %s') % volume_name) def manage_existing(self, volume, existing_ref): pass def manage_existing_get_size(self, volume, existing_ref): pass def unmanage(self, volume): pass def retype(self, context, volume, new_type, diff, host): pass def ensure_export(self, context, volume): volume_name = volume.get('id') LOG.debug('Checking existence of volume %s', volume_name) if self.api_client.find_volume(volume_name): return raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException( _('Unable to find volume %s') % volume_name) def create_export(self, context, volume, connector): pass def remove_export(self, context, volume): pass def create_consistencygroup(self, context, group): gid = group['id'] self.api_client.create_consistencygroup(gid) def delete_consistencygroup(self, context, group): gid = group['id'] self.api_client.delete_consistencygroup(gid) volumes = self.db.volume_get_all_by_group(context, gid) for volume in volumes: self.delete_volume(volume) volume['status'] = 'deleted' model_update = {'status': group['status']} return model_update, volumes def update_consistencygroup(self, context, group, add_volumes=None, remove_volumes=None): gid = group['id'] cg_group = self.api_client.find_consistencygroup(gid) if add_volumes: ret = self._add_cg_volumes(add_volumes, cg_group) if ret and remove_volumes: ret = self._remove_cg_volumes(remove_volumes, cg_group) def _add_cg_volumes(self, add_volumes, consistencygroup): for vol in add_volumes: consistencygroup.add_volume_to_group(vol) def _remove_cg_volumes(self, remove_volumes, consistencygroup): for vol in remove_volumes: consistencygroup.delete_volume_from_group(vol) def delete_cgsnapshot(self, context, cgsnapshot): snapshotid = cgsnapshot['id'] LOG.info(_LI('Deleting snapshot %(ss)s'), {'ss': snapshotid}) snapshots = objects.SnapshotList().get_all_for_cgsnapshot( context, snapshotid) for snapshot in snapshots: snapshot.status = 'deleted' model_update = {'status': 'deleted'} return model_update, snapshots def create_cgsnapshot(self, context, cgsnapshot): snapshotid = cgsnapshot['id'] LOG.debug('replayid %s', snapshotid) snapshots = objects.SnapshotList().get_all_for_cgsnapshot( context, snapshotid) for snapshot in snapshots: snapshot.status = 'available' model_update = {'status': 'available'} return model_update, snapshots def initialize_connection(self, volume, connector, initiator_data=None): pass def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs): pass

commit_message:
Validate name and description string

If you pass name or description parameters with more than 255
characters to create and update apis of volume and snapshot
and create api of backup, then it returns 500 error code.

Added new method validate_name_and_description() in
cinder.api.openstack.wsgi.Controllera to validate string limit and
returned 400 if limit exceeds and also removing leading or trailing
whitespaces and string containing only whitespaces.

APIImpact
1. For all above APIs 400 response will be returned.
2. Earlier it was possible to pass only whitespaces or leading-trailing
   spaces to 'name' parameter.
   Now it will raise 400 error if only whitespaces are passed and will
   remove leading-trailing spaces if present in other cases.

Conflicts:
	cinder/api/openstack/wsgi.py
	cinder/tests/api/contrib/test_backups.py
	cinder/tests/api/v2/test_snapshots.py
	cinder/tests/api/v2/test_volumes.py

Closes-Bug: 1454244
Change-Id: Iaf7159e816f69fd776a09828c3bc1d27fc9fdcdb
(cherry picked from commit a1bb185a1f0311c36fd590d48531ded6ccccc5c6)

commit_message:
Add extra spec capability for Nimble Cinder Driver

Supported Extra Specs are

1. Performance Policy Name
nimble:perfpol-name = <Performance Policy Name>

2. Encryption
nimble:encryption = "yes"

Implements: blueprint nimble-add-extra-specs-support

Change-Id: I45a18b189746b778f10eecbf669be7943828e28b
(cherry picked from commit 7093d0e290a6916db9eb244c187c56ebfa5b1990)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/18/233218/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.volume import volume_types DRIVER_VERSION = '1.1.0' AES_256_XTS_CIPHER = 2 DEFAULT_CIPHER = 3 EXTRA_SPEC_ENCRYPTION = 'nimble:encryption' EXTRA_SPEC_PERF_POLICY = 'nimble:perfpol-name' DEFAULT_PERF_POLICY_SETTING = 'default' DEFAULT_ENCRYPTION_SETTING = 'no' 1.1.0 - Added Extra Spec Capability def _get_volumetype_extraspecs(self, volume): specs = {} type_id = volume['volume_type_id'] if type_id is not None: specs = volume_types.get_volume_type_extra_specs(type_id) return specs def _get_extra_spec_values(self, extra_specs): """Nimble specific extra specs.""" perf_policy_name = extra_specs.get(EXTRA_SPEC_PERF_POLICY, DEFAULT_PERF_POLICY_SETTING) encryption = extra_specs.get(EXTRA_SPEC_ENCRYPTION, DEFAULT_ENCRYPTION_SETTING) return perf_policy_name, encryption specs = self._get_volumetype_extraspecs(volume) perf_policy_name, encrypt = self._get_extra_spec_values(specs) # default value of cipher for encryption cipher = DEFAULT_CIPHER if encrypt.lower() == 'yes': cipher = AES_256_XTS_CIPHER LOG.debug('Creating a new volume=%(vol)s size=%(size)s' ' reserve=%(reserve)s in pool=%(pool)s' ' description=%(description)s with Extra Specs' ' perfpol-name=%(perfpol-name)s' ' encryption=%(encryption)s cipher=%(cipher)s', {'vol': volume['name'], 'size': volume_size, 'reserve': reserve, 'pool': pool_name, 'description': description, 'perfpol-name': perf_policy_name, 'encryption': encrypt, 'cipher': cipher}) 'pool-name': pool_name, 'perfpol-name': perf_policy_name, 'encryptionAttr': {'cipher': cipher}}})
deleted_lines: DRIVER_VERSION = '1.0' LOG.info(_LI('Creating a new volume=%(vol)s size=%(size)s' ' reserve=%(reserve)s in pool=%(pool)s' ' description=%(description)s') % {'vol': volume['name'], 'size': volume_size, 'reserve': reserve, 'pool': pool_name, 'description': description}) 'perfpol-name': 'default', 'pool-name': pool_name}})

commit_message:
Fix 3PAR driver handling of existing VLUNs

Changes the 3PAR FC and iSCSI drivers to check for existing
VLUNs by taking into consideration both the volume and the host
when querying the backend.

Also pulled out some common code from the FC and iSCSI driver
to reduce duplicate code relating to the finding of existing
VLUNs.

Closes-Bug: #1475064
Change-Id: Id8fbdb5ae79274fb3d074f674df39f56db06f34d
(cherry picked from commit a07502f697fc7e45871d0099889841d03bfdf773)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/88/227088/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 2.0.42 - Changed initialize_connection to use getHostVLUNs. #1475064 VERSION = "2.0.42" def find_existing_vlun(self, volume, host): """Finds an existing VLUN for a volume on a host. Returns an existing VLUN's information. If no existing VLUN is found, None is returned. :param volume: A dictionary describing a volume. :param host: A dictionary describing a host. """ existing_vlun = None try: vol_name = self._get_3par_vol_name(volume['id']) host_vluns = self.client.getHostVLUNs(host['name']) # The first existing VLUN found will be returned. for vlun in host_vluns: if vlun['volumeName'] == vol_name: existing_vlun = vlun break except hpexceptions.HTTPNotFound: # ignore, no existing VLUNs were found pass return existing_vlun

commit_message:
Use of ast for integers doesn't changes type

ast.literal_eval doesn't change types for Integer
Booleans resulting in DBAPIError exceptions with
at least postgresql. Boolean columns need to be
explicitly cast to boolean types. This changes
the way filters are processed in the volume API.

APIImpact
Change-Id: Ice9c57fa99c17e4c87de6362bf30ed30503a1bed
Closes-Bug: #1494475

commit_message:
Get volume from db again before updating it's status

During uploading a volume which is attached to an instance to image service,
if the instance is deleted then the volume remains in "in-use" status.
So get the volume again from db before updating it's status.

Added new db api called 'volume_update_status_based_on_attachment'.
It gets volume from db and updates its status using the same session.

Closes-Bug: #1406703
Change-Id: I01d313438f021cd2fe0d6f5c23f2029279d4b55a
(cherry picked from commit 4d6ddcb94435a20476536f4956de88ce4ab15b66)

added_lines: def test_copy_volume_to_image_instance_deleted(self): # During uploading volume to image if instance is deleted, # volume should be in available status. self.image_meta['id'] = 'a440c04b-79fa-479c-bed1-0b816eaec379' # Creating volume testdata self.volume_attrs['instance_uuid'] = 'b21f957d-a72f-4b93-b5a5-' \ '45b1161abb02' db.volume_create(self.context, self.volume_attrs) # Storing unmocked db api function reference here, because we have to # update volume status (set instance_uuid to None) before calling the # 'volume_update_status_based_on_attached_instance_id' db api. unmocked_db_api = db.volume_update_status_based_on_attachment def mock_volume_update_after_upload(context, volume_id): # First update volume and set 'instance_uuid' to None # because after deleting instance, instance_uuid of volume is # set to None db.volume_update(context, volume_id, {'instance_uuid': None}) # Calling unmocked db api unmocked_db_api(context, volume_id) with mock.patch.object( db, 'volume_update_status_based_on_attachment', side_effect=mock_volume_update_after_upload) as mock_update: # Start test self.volume.copy_volume_to_image(self.context, self.volume_id, self.image_meta) # Check 'volume_update_status_after_copy_volume_to_image' # is called 1 time self.assertEqual(1, mock_update.call_count) # Check volume status has changed to available because # instance is deleted volume = db.volume_get(self.context, self.volume_id) self.assertEqual('available', volume['status'])

commit_message:
adds user_id to check_is_admin

A small tactical update to allow cinder to consider user_id
when checking for admin.

This is needed in the field until the larger changes around
admin scoping are completed. Checking for role only is not
sufficient in a multi-domain configuration.

juno-backport-potential
kilo-backport-potential

closes-bug: 968696

Change-Id: I0cb99186bd833c4c32964490c4bc6da9ad42d320
(cherry picked from commit 9840721b51671296816d681dbd4b9afe221f68b4)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/28/217728/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def check_is_admin(roles, context=None): """Whether or not user is admin according to policy setting. Can use roles or user_id from context to determine if user is admin. In a multi-domain configuration, roles alone may not be sufficient. if context is None: credentials = {'roles': roles} else: credentials = {'roles': context.roles, 'user_id': context.user_id }

commit_message:
Support libgfapi's backing file path format

Currently the _qemu_img_info_base method of remotefs driver
only allows the normal format of backing file's path. If nova
enables libgfapi, the backing file's path sometimes is looking
like this: gluster://<hostname/ip>:port/<volume_path>. And it
is not recognized by the driver. This patch is going to address
the issue.

Change-Id: I702ee1c92e0851869d3f9c4f0c65c8526cd39771
Closes-Bug: #1514691
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/16/243416/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: backing_file_normal_ptn = \ backing_file_libgfapi_ptn = \ "gluster://.*:[0-9]+/(.*/)?%" \ "(volname)s(.(tmp-snap-)?[0-9a-f-]+)?$" % { 'volname': volume_name } if not (re.match(backing_file_normal_ptn, info.backing_file) or re.match(backing_file_libgfapi_ptn, info.backing_file)):

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-01 17:24:51.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/test_driver.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/library.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/test_iscsi_driver.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/test_library.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/fakes.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/test_client.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/test_netapp_eseries_iscsi.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/test_fc_driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/3b9c900e9cac8f2c3f3f60cb18470684386f3759', 'message': 'NetApp: Refactor E-Series tests

Refactor the unittests for the NetApp E-Series drivers, removing
any functional tests and relocating tests underneath the
the path where the rest of the tests live.

commit_message:
NetApp: Refactor E-Series tests

Refactor the unittests for the NetApp E-Series drivers, removing
any functional tests and relocating tests underneath the
the path where the rest of the tests live.

Improve the coverage against the Fibre Channel E-Series driver
by refactoring the iSCSI tests to work generically where possible.

Change-Id: I30082859242cb5bc8d607ea2a6684a41f863b611

commit_message:
Support new ironic "enroll" state

This state was introduced in Liberty as a new state for freshly
enrolled node. Transition from it is done by the same verb "manage",
but now involves validation of power credentials. Nodes are not set to
"available" if they fail introspection or power credentials.

The code changes required some additional changes to test and utility
code, as follows:

 - utils.wait_for_provision_state now raises appropriate exceptions on
   error rather than returning False
 - there's now a utils.nodes_in_states function to list baremetal nodes
   in a given set of states.
 - logic is added to baremetal/fakes.py to track states of fake nodes;
   this is much simpler and less brittle than precisely mocking the
   results of API calls in exactly the order the library code makes
   them.
 - bulk introspection tests consistently mock at the client layer,
   rather than at a variety of layers.
 - timeout and power-credential error during bulk introspection are
   tested.

Change-Id: I4da61491f60f7ebd42ca1f8fe45c3d4df6e49887
Co-Authored-By: Miles Gould <mgould@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/52/260452/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
zmq: Don't log error when can't import zmq module

Method import_zmq returns None if can't import zmq module.
For runtime code, an ImportError is raised, and for tests,
a skip message "zmq not available" is sent, so it's unnecessary
to log error which shows up in other projects' unit test logs.

Co-Authored-By: Oleksii Zamiatin <ozamiatin@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: Iebf15042f45da56eb633a0a70822c487dc72c884
Closes-Bug: #1528415

commit_message:
Fix scenario tests for octavia driver

The current scenario tests were not waiting for the load balancer to become
ACTIVE while doing cleanups causing test failures.

Also, this increases a hardcoded timeout value of when a load balancer is
deemed to be stuck.  It was too short for the gate and the nested VMs issue of
boot taking 5-8 minutes.  I've increased it to 10 minutes.

A timeout was also needed when testing connectivity to a VIP because the
default timeout is way too long.

Change-Id: I667af547296ac707a6176d5c400ce025366e65ba

commit_message:
Fix python 3.x import issues with pure.py

The older import was not compatible with python 3.x, only 2.x. A simple
fix is to adjust how we are importing the module.

Change-Id: Ic1d69c676af1adde9bd305431338c16a058fccf6
Closes-Bug: 1527755

commit_message:
Fix image-download to stdout on Python 3.x

Glance image-download to stdout fails on Python3 due to sys.stdout.write
not allowing bytes to be written directly.

A good description of the issue is listed at http://bugs.python.org/issue18512

Closes-Bug: #1528083

Change-Id: I2963914e2e0744410267b5735ff77939413916d4

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-08 20:24:42.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/1ff70409d1aacff6c3f4d0b47371cfe5376d2fdc', 'message': 'Use branch-specific tox dir

Change the envdir used to build an env for unit
tests, to better support working on multiple
branches from the same base git dir.

This moves the tox environment into a directory
called "mitaka", so that the files used for
the mitaka tox env don't overlap with those used
for liberty.  The dir name should be bumped for
each release cycle.

This makes it possible to switch between branches

Change-Id: I76e57db089e3258ca71863fdf6c9bdc324197975
'}]
commit_message:
Use branch-specific tox dir

Change the envdir used to build an env for unit
tests, to better support working on multiple
branches from the same base git dir.

This moves the tox environment into a directory
called "mitaka", so that the files used for
the mitaka tox env don't overlap with those used
for liberty.  The dir name should be bumped for
each release cycle.

This makes it possible to switch between branches
which have conflicting dependencies in the tox
env and have tox test commands work as expected.

Change-Id: I76e57db089e3258ca71863fdf6c9bdc324197975
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/45/254945/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: toxworkdir = {toxinidir}/.tox/mitaka/

commit_message:
Make Keystone_endpoint match service by name/type

Since a chance in puppet-keystone (1], we now match an endpoint with a
service name/type.
This patch reflects this change for 'image' service endpoint.
)
[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/?id=0a4e06abb0f5b3f324464ff5219d2885816311ce

Closes-Bug: #1528308

Change-Id: Idff0ff4052ee9db4395a0b556f4c01c5538450dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/44/260044/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Update fuel_deployment to 0.3.0

* Reimplement graph plot method
* Add weights feature
* Change process to cluster
* Add tests

commit_message:
Release os-client-config 0.13.0

There is a new helper method that keystone wants to use, and there are
several minor additions we want for python-novaclient.

commit_message:
Make kubernetes API client generic

Make kubernetes API client generic. Right now each k8s object has
a way to create k8s API client. This was needed to make sure the
tests passed. Now since all the objects-from-bay patches are merged
in its better to make the client creation logic generic.

Change-Id: Ic2a9b16bbd4c13794c7ef95309bd260366ec872e
Closes-Bug: #1502367
